questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the office because of several episodes of dark-brown urine. He first noticed it 2 weeks ago. The patient’s parent adds that the patient has also been getting easily tired lately and frequently takes naps after school. There is no family history of renal conditions or hearing abnormalities. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/89 mmHg. Physical examination shows periorbital and generalized edema. Vision and hearing screening are normal. Laboratory results are as follows:


Renal biopsy findings show thickening of glomerular basement membrane due to dense deposits and mesangial ingrowth appearing as “tram-tracks.” Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?

choices.text: Mesangial deposition of insoluble polymers of proteins

questions.solution:
This young boy with nephrotic-range proteinuria (3+ on urine dipstick), hematuria, edema, hypertension, and biopsy findings of thickened glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and mesangial ingrowth in between most likely has type II membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN).  

MPGN is defined as a pattern of glomerular injury that involves thickening of the GBM with mesangial ingrowth in between, forming the classic tram-track appearance. It mainly occurs in children and presents with nephrotic syndrome, nephritic syndrome or a combination of both. MPGN is divided into three types. Type II is a result of widespread activation of C3, which occurs due to the persistent activity of the enzyme C3 convertase. Its activity is upregulated by autoantibodies called C3 nephritic factors. Immunofluorescence shows granular deposits of C3 within (intramembranous) and along the GBM.  


Type I, on the other hand, is mainly immune complex-mediated MPGN resulting from chronic antigenemia and is usually seen in chronic infections (hepatitis B or C infection) or autoimmune conditions. Histologically, it is characterized by discrete immune deposits in the mesangium and subendothelial space.


Option Analysis

✅ C3 nephritic factor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mutation in type IV collagen:
Incorrect: Mutation in type IV collagen is seen in Alport syndrome, a hereditary form of nephritis that is usually associated with sensorineural hearing loss and ocular abnormalities. Renal biopsy findings include thinning and splitting of glomerular basement membrane.
❌ Proteinase 3 antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (PR3-ANCA/c-ANCA):
Incorrect: These autoantibodies against neutrophil granule proteins are seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly called Wegener granulomatosis). The condition is an immune-mediated disorder and is usually associated with fever, weight loss and recurrent sinopulmonary infections. Renal biopsy is associated with few or no immune deposits in the glomeruli.
❌ T-cell dysfunction:
Incorrect: T-cell dysfunction is considered a major pathogenic factor in minimal change disease (MCD), which usually presents in children with nephrotic syndrome. Although this patient’s proteinuria is in the nephrotic range, the coexisting nephritic syndrome (hematuria, edema, hypertension, RBC casts) and abnormal biopsy findings (typically normal in MCD) make this condition unlikely.
❌ Mesangial deposition of insoluble polymers of proteins:
Incorrect: Mesangial deposition of insoluble polymers of proteins (e.g. amyloid) is seen in amyloidosis. Renal involvement usually presents with asymptomatic proteinuria or clinically apparent nephrotic syndrome. Renal biopsy findings include mesangial deposits of amyloid that can be observed with Congo red staining as apple-green birefringence under polarized light.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with rapid, shallow breathing and rapid heart rate. He recently came back from a trip to Nepal where he went mountain climbing. The patient has no past medical history, and he has recently been taking acetazolamide for altitude sickness. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 102/70 mmHg. Arterial blood gas and laboratory testing are obtained, and the results are shown below.


Which of the following parts of the nephron is most likely affected by this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with hyperventilation, history of acetazolamide (carbonic anhydrase inhibitor) use, hypokalemia, urine pH below 5.5, and normal anion gap metabolic acidosis has a proximal (type 2) renal tubular acidosis (RTA). 



Proximal RTA is caused by a genetic or acquired defect of the brush border cells of the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) that prevents bicarbonate reabsorption. The increased bicarbonate excretion via urine leads to an overabundance of hydrogen ions in the blood and metabolic acidosis. Also, the high urine bicarbonate concentration leads to osmotic diuresis and mild hypovolemia. This fluid shift leads to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), increased sodium reabsorption, and increased potassium excretion. As a result, patients develop hypokalemia. Unlike in distal (type 1) RTA, however, the distal intercalated cells are still functional in patients with proximal RTA and can secrete hydrogen ions, so urine pH is below 5.5.  





The most common cause of proximal RTA is Fanconi syndrome, which is defined as generalized proximal tubule dysfunction. Other causes include carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g. acetazolamide) and hypergammaglobulinemic states (e.g., monoclonal gammopathy, multiple myeloma).    

In this patient, acetazolamide led to development of a proximal RTA. Discontinuing the offending agent would lead to symptom resolution.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: The arrow in this picture points to the glomerulus. Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes affect the glomerulus. However, this patient has findings consistent with a proximal (type 2) renal tubular acidosis (RTA), which is due to defective bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule. 
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: The arrow in this picture points to the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. This patient with proximal (type 2) renal tubular acidosis (RTA) has defective bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule.  
❌ :
Incorrect: The arrow in this picture points to the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). However, this patient has a low serum pH, hypokalemia, and urine pH < 5.5, which is consistent with a proximal (type 2) renal tubular acidosis (RTA). Type 2 RTA affects the proximal convoluted tubule.
❌ :
Incorrect: The arrow in this picture points to the collecting duct, which is affected in distal (type 1) renal tubular acidosis (RTA). Potential causes of type 1 RTA include medications (e.g., amphotericin B analgesics), congenital urinary tract anomalies, and autoimmune diseases (e.g. SLE). However, type I RTA would present with a urine pH greater than 5.5.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of generalized body swelling. The swelling started 2 days ago when his parent noticed swelling around the patient’s eyes. Review of systems reveals mild shortness of breath after climbing a flight of stairs. The patient experienced an episode of flu-like symptoms and throat pain 2 weeks ago that responded to over-the-counter medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 155/92 mmHg. Physical examination shows periorbital pitting edema and 1+ generalized pitting edema. Pulmonary exam reveals bilateral fine expiratory crackles in the lower lobes. Complete blood count is normal. Serum chemistries and urinalysis findings are as follows:


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient with generalized edema, dyspnea, and hypertension, as well as hematuria, red blood cell casts, and mild proteinuria on urinalysis most likely has poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).  

PSGN is a result of a type III hypersensitivity reaction in response to bacterial M protein (virulence factor) that results in the formation of antigen-antibody complexes on the glomerular basement membrane, which then leads to complement activation and inflammation, resulting in nephritic syndrome. It usually occurs 2-4 weeks after a streptococcal pharyngeal (as in this patient) or skin (e.g. impetigo) infection. Clinical features and laboratory findings are described in the table below.


The prognosis is good, and renal biopsy is usually not indicated except for refractory cases. If a biopsy is performed, the histology reveals diffusely enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli, RBC casts in nephron tubules, and interstitial edema and inflammation. Electron microscopy shows antigen-antibody complexes as subepithelial deposits or “humps” along the glomerular basement membrane. These complexes can also be seen on immunofluorescence microscopy as granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3.  


Reproduced from:




Option Analysis

❌ Type II hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Type II hypersensitivity reaction involves antibodies binding to cell-surface antigens, resulting in cellular destruction and inflammation. Goodpasture syndrome is a notable example of type II HSR that causes rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. However, it instead presents in the third decade of life with hematuria and hemoptysis, and it would not be associated with high ASO titers, such as in this patient.
✅ Type III hypersensitivity reaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Type IV hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: In type IV hypersensitivity reaction, CD8+ T cells are involved in direct cell cytotoxicity and inflammation. Examples include contact dermatitis with poison ivy, PPD-induced skin induration and graft-versus-host disease. It does not involve antibodies, as seen in this patient with elevated ASO titers.
❌ Leukemoid reaction:
Incorrect: A leukemoid reaction is an increase in the leukocyte count which can mimic leukemia. The reaction is typically due to an infection or another disease. This patient’s body temperature and leukocyte count is normal.
❌ Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction:
Incorrect: This is a reaction whereby endotoxin-like molecules are released by the death of microorganisms, inducing an inflammatory response. It is uncommon and is observed during antibiotic treatment for spirochetal infection (e.g. syphilis). It usually manifests as fever, rigors, hypotension and tachycardia, not dyspnea and hematuria.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to the office because of a cough and bloody sputum for 3 weeks. The onset of symptoms was preceded by sore throat and mild nasal congestion. He has no fever, weight loss, night sweats, or complaints of recurrent infections, but he does describe several episodes of red-colored urine. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 152/88 mmHg. Physical examination shows bilateral inspiratory crackles. There is 1+ peripheral pitting edema. Chest x-ray reveals bilateral infiltrates. Serum creatinine is 3.2 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows mild proteinuria, hematuria, and red blood cell casts. Renal biopsy specimen under immunofluorescence microscopy is shown:


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has nephritic syndrome (hematuria, hypertension, mild proteinuria), accompanied by hemoptysis and immunofluorescence findings of linear deposits along the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), which suggests a diagnosis of anti-GBM disease, previously called Goodpasture syndrome.  

Anti-GBM disease is an uncommon cause of glomerulonephritis that is caused by autoimmune antibodies directed against the components of the GBM (e.g. alpha 3 chain of type IV collagen). Antibody formation may be triggered by an antecedent viral upper respiratory infection but can be idiopathic. The antibodies induce a type II hypersensitivity reaction resulting in basement membrane damage of glomeruli and alveoli, leading to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) and alveolar hemorrhage.  

RPGN presents with nephritic syndrome. On renal biopsy, light microscopy reveals crescent-shaped deposits of fibrin, C3, and mononuclear cells. Immunofluorescence microscopy is characterized by linear deposits of IgG and complement along the GBM, a finding specific to anti-GBM disease. Alveolar hemorrhage presents with hemoptysis, cough, and dyspnea with infiltrates seen on chest x-ray.  

Treatment of anti-GBM disease includes plasmapheresis accompanied by immunosuppressants, such as glucocorticoids and cyclophosphamide. Plasmapheresis removes circulating anti-GBM antibodies and other mediators of inflammation, and the immunosuppressive agents minimize new antibody formation.

Option Analysis

❌ Granulomatosis with polyangiitis:
Incorrect: Although granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) may also present with hemoptysis and nephritic syndrome, it is usually accompanied by fatigue, fever, weight loss, and history of recurrent rhinosinusitis. Chest x-ray shows necrotizing nodular or cavitary lesions, not interstitial infiltrates. Moreover, renal biopsy specimen under immunofluorescence microscopy reveals no deposits (pauci-immune), as opposed to this patient’s linear deposits along the glomerular basement membrane.
✅ Anti-glomerular basement membrane syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a granulomatous, necrotizing, small vessel vasculitis that is associated with atopy, sinusitis, purpura, peripheral neuropathy and/or eosinophilia. When it involves the kidneys, it causes pauci-immune glomerulonephritis, in which no deposition is seen on immunofluorescence microscopy, as opposed to this patient’s linear deposits along the glomerular basement membrane.
❌ Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis:
Incorrect: Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis is usually associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and often presents with findings of both nephritic and nephrotic syndromes. Renal biopsy findings include wire looping of capillaries on light microscopy. Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals granular immune complex deposits, as opposed to this patient’s linear deposits along the glomerular basement membrane. Additionally, pulmonary symptoms would be atypical.
❌ Amyloidosis:
Incorrect: Pulmonary findings in amyloidosis are limited to pleural effusions and parenchymal nodules, while renal involvement usually presents with asymptomatic proteinuria or clinically apparent nephrotic (not nephritic) syndrome. Renal biopsy findings include mesangial deposits of amyloid that are observed in Congo red staining as apple-green birefringence under polarized light.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman comes to the office because of several episodes of dark brown urine. The episodes started 3 weeks ago. She has no recent history of skin infection, flu or diarrhea. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for deafness in her mother and renal failure in her maternal grandfather. She has a 26-year-old brother who is healthy. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 142/84 mmHg. Physical examination reveals 1+ generalized pitting edema. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral yellow granulations in the retina suggestive of retinopathy. Complete blood count is normal. Urinalysis is shown below:


Renal biopsy findings reveal thinning and splitting of glomerular basement membrane. Which of the following is the most likely mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
The findings of retinopathy, nephritic syndrome (hematuria, periorbital edema, dysmorphic RBCs), and a family history of deafness and renal failure are classic for Alport syndrome.  

Alport syndrome (also known as hereditary nephritis) is a hereditary disorder that is caused by mutations in genes encoding members of the type IV collagen family which are found in the basement membranes of glomerulus (GBM) and cochlea, in addition to the lens capsule. It is mostly inherited in an X-linked dominant fashion, in which transmission can occur through both sexes. Mothers with a disease-causing X chromosome (XnX) can transmit it to both sons and daughters, while fathers can only transmit to daughters but not sons.  



The abnormal collagen results in progressive glomerular disease that is often associated with sensorineural hearing loss and ocular manifestations (anterior lenticonus, retinopathy). The condition is diagnosed on molecular genetic testing or renal biopsy. The latter reveals the characteristic finding of longitudinal splitting of the lamina densa of the GBM, making its appearance as a basket-weave under electron microscopy. Immunostaining for type IV collagen shows absence or discontinuous distribution of the alpha chains.

Option Analysis

❌ X-linked recessive:
Incorrect: Phenotypic expression of an X-linked recessive disorder is dependent on the sex of the child. All the males who inherit the defective X-chromosome display the phenotype whereas only homozygous females do (which is a very rare occurrence). As a result, the disorder cannot manifest in females in two consecutive generations.
✅ X-linked dominant:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mitochondrial:
Incorrect: Mitochondrial DNA is only inherited from the mother, and disorders transmitted by mitochondrial inheritance are seen in all the progeny with variable expressivity. This patient’s maternal grandfather transmitted the disease to her mother, making this inheritance pattern very unlikely. Moreover, the patient’s brother is unaffected. Examples of mitochondrial diseases are Leber hereditary optic neuropathy and myoclonic epilepsy.
❌ Multifactorial:
Incorrect: Multifactorial inheritance involves numerous genetic and environmental factors that interact to determine phenotypic expression. Examples include neural tube defects, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. In general, these conditions have a lower risk of recurrence as compared to single-gene disorders.
❌ Autosomal recessive:
Incorrect: Phenotypic expression of autosomal recessive disorders require both parents to be carriers of the disease. It is usually observed in disorders with enzyme deficiencies like cystic fibrosis and glycogen storage diseases. This patient’s mother and maternal grandfather variably expressed the disease manifestations, making this mode of inheritance unlikely.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided flank pain and dark urine for the past few hours. The patient states, “I thought my back was acting up again so I took two extra naproxen today. I decided to come get checked out once my urine appeared dark.” The patient denies dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, fever or chills. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, chronic lumbosacral back pain and migraine headaches. Current medications include phenacetin, acetaminophen, ibuprofen, naproxen and insulin. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8° F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Serum creatinine is 1.9 mg/dL. Urinalysis is shown.  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Urinalysis 
 Color  Clear 
 Specific gravity  1.013 
 Protein  1.0 g/day 
 Blood  Positive 
 Leukocyte esterase  Negative 
 Leukocytes  1-2/hpf 
 Erythrocytes  40-42/hpf 
 Dysmorphic RBCs  Absent 
 Casts  None 
   
Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s hematuria?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of acute onset colicky flank pain, hematuria, long-term history of analgesic consumption, and presence of erythrocytes on urinalysis is strongly suggestive of renal papillary necrosis (RPN).  

This condition results from ischemia of the renal papillae due to decreased blood flow through the small caliber arteries feeding this region. Diminished perfusion may result either from mechanical obstruction, inflammation or vasoconstriction--ultimately resulting in necrosis and sloughing of the papillae causing hematuria and colicky flank pain. Associated conditions include: 
  •  Sickle cell disease/trait, in which sickled cells cause mechanical obstruction of renal vessels. 
  •  Diabetes mellitus, which can cause renal atherosclerosis and subsequently hypoperfusion. 
  • Analgesic nephropathy, wherein analgesics, including NSAIDs, reduce renal perfusion by inhibiting prostaglandin production, which leads to constriction of renal afferent arterioles. 
  •  Acute pyelonephritis, wherein the inflamed kidney may compress against the renal vasculature, resulting in hypoperfusion and ischemia.

Option Analysis

❌ Urinary tract infection:
Incorrect: Urinary tract infection may present with flank pain and hematuria, but it is unlikely in this patient with normal vitals and a negative leukocyte esterase on urinalysis. 
❌ Nephritic syndrome:
Incorrect: Although hematuria and proteinuria are observed in nephritic syndrome, this condition is typically accompanied by hypertension, red blood cell casts, and dysmorphic red blood cells. 
❌ Renal artery stenosis:
Incorrect: Renal artery stenosis presents with treatment resistant hypertension, flash pulmonary edema, or an acute rise in serum creatinine following ACEI or ARB administration. This patient’s normal blood pressure negates this diagnosis. 
❌ Hemolytic uremic syndrome:
Incorrect: Hemolytic uremic syndrome occurs in response to shiga-like toxin-producing organisms and presents with the triad of acute kidney injury, hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia one to two weeks following a diarrheal illness. 
✅ Renal papillary necrosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of headaches, palpitations, and muscle pain for the last 2 months. The patient’s medical history is non-contributory, and she is not currently taking any medications. The patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 186/92 mmHg. The physician prescribes lisinopril 10 mg and recommends a follow up in one month. One month later, the patient returns to the clinic with persistent symptoms. Upon further questioning, the patient admits to consumption of five cups of Egpytian licorice tea daily for the past six months. Laboratory tests are obtained, and the results are shown below:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
Blood, serum, plasma 
Potassium   3.2 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  44 mEq/L 
 Aldosterone  decreased 
 Renin  decreased 
Which of the following enzymes is most likely inhibited in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with headaches, palpitations, muscle pain, treatment-resistant hypertension, and chronic licorice (glycyrrhetinic acid) consumption most likely has an acquired form of the syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME).   

SAME can be hereditary or acquired. In its inherited form, SAME is an autosomal recessive disorder that is caused by an inhibition or deficiency of 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase in the collecting duct of the nephron. Normally, this enzyme converts cortisol to cortisone, a less potent hormone; therefore, a decrease in enzyme activity leads to increased levels of cortisol. Excess cortisol binds and over-activates mineralocorticoid receptors in the collecting duct of the kidneys, which mimics the effects of aldosterone.

Thus serum aldosterone levels are low, but the patient’s clinical presentation is consistent with hyperaldosteronism. This includes increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion, leading to hypertension and hypokalemia. The kidneys will attempt to compensate for these changes by increasing the activity of the K+/H+ ATPase in the collecting duct. This will lead to increased hydrogen ion secretion and metabolic alkalosis.  

One common cause of acquired SAME is chronic licorice consumption, because licorice contains glycyrrhetinic acid, which can inhibit 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase.  Treatment for SAME includes normalizing potassium levels, identifying the underlying cause, discontinuing the offending agent, and regular monitoring of patient’s blood pressure.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ 17α-hydroxylase:
Incorrect: 17α-hydroxylase deficiency is associated with a type of congenital adrenal hyperplasia with increased mineralocorticoids, decreased cortisol, and decreased sex hormones. The patient’s age decreases the likelihood of a congenital adrenal hyperplasia.  
❌ 21-hydroxylase:
Incorrect: 21-hydroxylase deficiency is associated with a type of congenital adrenal hyperplasia with decreased mineralocorticoids, decreased cortisol, and increased sex hormones. The patient’s hypertension and age decrease the likelihood of a congenital adrenal hyperplasia.  
✅ 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 11β-hydroxylase:
Incorrect: 11β-hydroxylase deficiency is associated with a type of congenital adrenal hyperplasia with decreased aldosterone, increased 11-deoxycorticosterone (which functions as a mineralocorticoid in excess), decreased cortisol, and increased sex hormones. The patient’s age decreases the likelihood of this diagnosis.  
❌ 5α-reductase:
Incorrect: 5α-reductase deficiency is associated with an inability to convert testosterone into dihydrotestosterone. The patient’s age and symptoms suggest a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the office because of facial puffiness. Her parent states that the patient has been easily fatigued and has had red-colored urine for the past several days. Past medical history is significant for a throat infection 3 weeks ago that was treated with amoxicillin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg. Physical examination shows periorbital edema and 2+ pitting edema along the ankles bilaterally. Blood urea nitrogen is 30 mg/dL, and serum creatinine is 1.6 mg/dL. Which of the following sets of findings will most likely be seen on urinalysis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with edema, hematuria, fatigue and hypertension, together with increased blood urea nitrogen (azotemia) makes nephritic syndrome the most likely diagnosis. The recent history of throat infection treated with amoxicillin points towards poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).  

Nephritic syndrome is the result of glomerular inflammation that can be due to a number of causes, such as PSGN. It causes glomerular basement membrane (GBM) damage that results in leaking of red blood cells (hematuria) and albumin (proteinuria) into urine. Hematuria and red blood cell (RBC) casts disrupt the glomerular filtration, leading to oliguria, pyuria, azotemia, increased renin release, and consequent hypertension. Hematuria due to glomerular disease can be distinguished from that due to other causes (e.g., nephrolithiasis, cancer) by urinalysis findings showing RBC casts and dysmorphic RBCs, which are only seen in glomerulonephritis.  


The findings mentioned above can be seen on urinalysis. Additional investigations helpful in determining the specific cause include serum complement levels (usually decreased in diseases involving immune complex formation, such as PSGN) and antibody screening (e.g., antistreptolysin O, anti-double stranded DNA). Definitive diagnosis of a particular disease process requires renal biopsy.

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: These findings are seen in acute interstitial nephritis. This condition is usually the result of a hypersensitivity to certain drugs (e.g., diuretics, NSAIDs, penicillin) and often presents with fever, rash, hematuria and costovertebral angle tenderness. The interstitial inflammation results in pyuria (classically eosinophils) and the formation of white blood cells casts.
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: This set of findings is classic for nephrotic syndrome. This condition usually occurs due to glomerular podocyte damage resulting in an impaired charge barrier and subsequent proteinuria. It is associated with a hypercoagulable state (due to renal loss of antithrombin III) and increased risk of infection (due to renal loss of immunoglobulins and complement factors), not hypertension, azotemia and hematuria as seen in this patient.
❌ :
Incorrect: Hyaline casts are nonspecific and can be seen on a normal urinalysis. These casts are the result of solidification of Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein that is secreted by renal tubular cells. The sloughing can sometimes be increased during exercise or diuretics use.
❌ :
Incorrect: Granular “muddy-brown” casts of tubular epithelial cells are seen in acute tubular necrosis. This condition is usually a result of ischemic or nephrotoxic injury to kidney tubules that clinically presents with oliguria and uremia, followed by a recovery phase in which polyuria is seen. It does not cause nephritic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man is brought to office because of bumps on his arms and blood in his urine for the past 2 weeks. The bumps are non-pruritic but painful to touch. He has not had a recent upper respiratory infection, hemoptysis, or facial rashes. Past medical history is significant for allergic rhinitis and poorly-controlled asthma, diagnosed 10 years ago. He takes doses of inhaled corticosteroids. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows periorbital edema and a transverse nasal crease. Subcutaneous nodules are noted on the extensor surface of the arms and forearms and are tender to palpation. Laboratory evaluation is shown:

Renal biopsy findings show glomerular crescent formation. Which of the following additional laboratory findings is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has nephritic syndrome (hematuria, edema, proteinuria and red blood cell casts) in association with a history of atopic disorders (rhinitis, asthma), eosinophilia, and subcutaneous tender nodules. Together with renal biopsy findings of glomerular crescent formation, the most likely diagnosis is eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA).  

EGPA, formerly called Churg-Strauss syndrome, is a multisystem small-vessel vasculitis that occurs due to abnormalities in immune function that are not well-understood. The result is eosinophilic infiltration and formation of necrotizing granulomas in the involved organs. It is usually associated with atopic disorders (allergic rhinitis, asthma) and can present with nephritic syndrome (rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis), skin nodules or purpura (cutaneous), wrist/foot drop (neuropathy) and abdominal pain/diarrhea (gastrointestinal). Laboratory findings include normocytic anemia, leukocytosis, eosinophilia, and myeloperoxidase antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (MPO-ANCA), also known as p-ANCA, which are found in up to 60 percent cases of EGPA.  

Definitive diagnosis is usually made on biopsy of the involved organs (e.g. skin), which reveals eosinophilic infiltration and noncaseating granulomas. Renal biopsy reveals characteristic fibrin and C3 deposition in the form of a crescent.


Glucocorticoids are the mainstay of treatment for EGPA due to their immunosuppressive effects. Severe or refractory disease requires addition of cyclophosphamide or immunosuppressive agents (azathioprine, methotrexate).

Option Analysis

✅ Myeloperoxidase antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Proteinase 3 antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies:
Incorrect: PR3-ANCA/c-ANCA autoantibodies against neutrophil granule proteins are seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), formerly called Wegener granulomatosis. Though the condition does cause crescentic glomerulonephritis, eosinophilia is not present and skin nodules are uncommon. Additionally, since GPA also affects the pulmonary parenchyma, hemoptysis is commonly seen.
❌ Elevated antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers:
Incorrect: Antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers are usually high in poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), which is commonly seen in children with a history of group A streptococcus pharyngitis or impetigo. Although the patient presents with nephritic syndrome, eosinophilia is atypical and renal biopsy instead shows hypercellular glomeruli and subepithelial humps.
❌ Anti-double stranded DNA antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-dsDNA antibodies are usually found in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). When it involves kidneys, SLE causes diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis, which is seen on renal biopsy specimen as GBM thickening and wire-looping of capillaries. Common skin manifestations include the classic malar rash and discoid rash. Tender subcutaneous nodules are rare.
❌ Hepatitis B surface antigen:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B virus seropositivity is associated with several conditions like type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) and polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). The former is differentiated on renal biopsy findings of subepithelial deposits and tram-track appearance of the GBM, while the latter is a vasculitis that can cause renal microaneurysms but does not involve glomeruli.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents to the primary care physician with facial puffiness. The patient’s parent states, “He seems like he's gained some weight recently, and he's always complaining about his feet hurting now.” She reports the patient had a “sore throat” 2-4 weeks ago. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 100/64 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 96% on room air. On physical exam, a comfortable appearing boy is noted to have 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities. The posterior pharynx is without erythema or exudate. Cardiopulmonary exam demonstrates normal heart sounds and clear lung fields bilaterally. The patient is asked to provide a urine sample, and it is noted to appear frothy. Which of the following pathophysiologic processes is most likely contributing to this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This 8-year-old boy presents with weight gain, pitting edema, and frothy urine in the setting of a recent infection. This presentation is most consistent with the nephrotic syndrome due to minimal change disease. The condition leads to a decrease in intravascular plasma volume and in response, the body increases aldosterone and ADH secretion.   

Nephrotic syndrome is a spectrum of disease states characterized by massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and edema due to disruption of the glomerular filtration charge barrier. Disruption of the charge barrier formed by podocytes causes large proteins (e.g., albumin, antithrombin III) to be excreted via urine, resulting in decreased plasma oncotic pressure. As plasma oncotic pressure decreases, fluid moves from the intravascular space into the interstitial space, causing edema. Intravascular volume depletion activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system to improve sodium and water retention. Moreover, due to decreased oncotic pressure, the liver attempts to compensate by increasing lipoprotein synthesis, resulting in hyperlipidemia.  



Option Analysis

✅ Increased aldosterone and ADH secretion:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Decreased lipoprotein synthesis :
Incorrect: Increased lipoprotein synthesis, not decreased synthesis, is observed in patients with nephrotic syndrome. This phenomenon occurs as a compensatory mechanism due to the large losses of protein (primarily albumin) via urine. 
❌ Increased oncotic pressure :
Incorrect: This patient has frothy urine and pitting edema in the lower extremities, which raises concern for nephrotic syndrome. Oncotic pressure in nephrotic syndrome is decreased, not increased, due to excess proteinuria.
❌ Hypercellular and inflamed glomeruli:
Incorrect: Nephritic syndromes are primarily driven by inflamed glomeruli. The inflammation can be due to disease states such as acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, and Alport syndrome. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is on the differential for this patient. However, urine in patients with nephritic syndrome is typically tea-colored or cola-colored. 
❌ Poor cardiac ejection fraction:
Incorrect: Poor cardiac ejection fraction may cause symptoms of edema, including pitting of the lower extremities and pleural effusions. However, this patient has no major risk factors or clinical stigmata for heart failure, myocarditis, or dilated cardiomyopathy.
